data.title: Review: A Certain Idea of France: The Life of Charles de Gaulle by Julian Jackson — the ‘brutally divisive’ general who saved France
data.meta_description: The legend of Charles de Gaulle still looms over the country he came to embody. “As France shrinks,” writes Julian Jackson in his hugely impressive new biography, “de Gaulle seems to grow,” and it seems that he “increasingly floats free of the history of which he was the protagonist”. In an editoria
data.text:
The legend of Charles de Gaulle still looms over the country he came to embody. “As France shrinks,” writes Julian Jackson in his hugely impressive new biography, “de Gaulle seems to grow,” and it seems that he “increasingly floats free of the history of which he was the protagonist”.

In an editorial of 2010 to mark the 40th anniversary of his death, Le Monde declared that the French were still “orphans of de Gaulle”, and Emmanuel Macron’s official presidential photograph shows him with an open copy of de Gaulle’s War Memoirs, the first sentence of which (“All my life I have had a certain idea of France”) supplies Jackson with his title.

Jackson, a professor of modern French history at Queen Mary University of
